Award.AbstractNarration:
A request is made to fund Oceanographic Instrumentation for the R/V Hugh R Sharp, a 146-foot Regional research vessel operated by the University of Delaware as part of the University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS) research fleet.

The R/V Hugh R Sharp is a state-of-the-art, coastal research vessel that is owned and operated by the University of Delaware. The vessel can carry fourteen to twenty scientists on cruises up to eighteen days in duration, and supports projects from all disciplines of oceanography. The vessel is a regional asset, serving researchers from many institutions throughout the mid-Atlantic. The vessel typically operates in the coastal waters from Long Island, New York, to Cape Hatteras, North Carolina, as well as the Delaware and Chesapeake Bays. Projects occasionally require the vessel to work as far north as the Gulf of Maine, as far south as Florida, and as far offshore as Bermuda. In 2017, the R/V Hugh R Sharp completed 174 days at sea. NSF funded projects accounted for 16 days or 10% of the sailing schedule. In 2018, R/V Hugh R Sharp is scheduled for 99 days with NSF days accounting for 31% (30 days) of the total sailing schedule. Oceanographic Instrumentation requested in this proposal includes:
1) POS MV Replacement $90,000
2) Big Eye Binoculars $37,000
3) Fiber Optic Fusion Splicer $20,000
$147,000
Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 13-589). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

University of Delaware R/V HUGH R. SHARP

NSF Organization Unit

OCE – Oceanographic Instrumentation

Funding Code

5413

Project Description

Our technical support group and members from the Oregon State University Ship Technical Support group have recently completed an industry sponsored fiber optic training class. Through the class and discussion with the two technical support groups, it was determined that, in our roll of technical support, there should be a set of support equipment. This equipment would include the above-mentioned support kit. It was also evident that it would be more reliable and a lower power loss termination if a fused splice was used instead of end connectors or mechanical splicing terminations. End connectors can be difficult to accomplish and have a higher power loss profile than splicing a pigtail end on. There are two methods of splicing pigtail connection ends on to a working fiber optic cable, mechanical and fusion. The mechanical splice, basically clamps the two ends

of the fiber in a reflective gel. The fusions splice actually heat melts the two ends of the glass fiber and cladding together. It actually becomes one component not two clamped together. This means that it is the most reliable method and provides the best power loss results. In the operational situations where we use the fiber optic cables, this reliability is key. The projects are mission critical and dependent on the performance of the fiber optic cable system. Therefore, we are requesting funding to acquire a fusion splicing system and supplies to support these science missions.

 With the recommendations of both the Jason support group at WHOI and the University of Delaware IT department and the training we received in December 2017, we are confident in the equipment we are requesting. These two proposed pieces of equipment provide the groundwork for supporting the cable. The Fiber Optic Test Instrument examines the cable to determine that the cable is in good condition and that all splices are functional. The fusion splicer can save many man-hours when compared with doing manual mechanical splices. It is our understanding and observation that a fusion splice is the most efficient method for accomplishing this process. Because the Oregon State University Tech Group also attended the training course in December 2017 and was aware of our efforts in fiber optic cable support, this equipment has already been shared for their science support needs. In addition, we could provide backup, if needed, to the Jason group’s equipment.

Fiber Optic Fusion Splicer

This project is now complete. The Fiber optic fusion splicer was purchased and tested. It is now part of a fleet wide user pool of fiber optic tools. Due to time and price changes, the purchase of the fusion splicer came in under budget. The following two sub-projects were approved (see appendix) and all items purchased. These items will be installed and put into service during the winter maintenance period.

 

  1. Back Up Slip Ring - Currently, we only have one slip-ring for the fiber optic cable and winch system. If there were any failure in the slip-ring either in the copper wires connections or the fiber-optic connections, the fiber optic system would be unusable. When in use for a project, this system is a high priority system for the project. The parts for this system also have significant repair/replacement lead times. Therefore, a failure could mean a significant loss of science time and ship days.

 

  1. Upgraded Junction Boxes - The current J-box for the fiber optic is inadequate due to two key points. First, the fibers are not properly supported in a work loop support frame and second, it is difficult to perform any troubleshooting with a jumble of fibers and copper wires. This has been a point of ST-connector failure during science project missions. By purchasing proper fiber optic termination J-boxes and properly supporting the fibers cables within, we attempt to eliminate this area of failure. With fixed points of connection and labeling, we strive to make troubleshooting more effective.
